data.text: Contents
Introduction

To reflect the climate on corporate governance issues, it is both appropriate and necessary to formally set out current treasury activities and establish a treasury risk management environment in which all objectives, policies and operating parameters are clearly defined.
In this context, Treasury management is the efficient management of liquidity and financial risks in the Trust.
Scope

This policy provides a clearly defined risk management framework for the Trust and those staff in the Trust responsible for treasury operations. Actions to manage this risk will vary over time and the policy will be reviewed regularly to reflect any changes in the Trust's operations and the on-going financial climate.
The policy is divided into the following sections:
Objectives
Attitude to investment risk
Organisation and Responsibilities
Bank Relationships and Cash Management
Reporting
Performance Management
Controls
Definitions
Objectives
The objectives of the Treasury Management Policy are to:
a) Ensure the most competitive return on surplus cash balances within an agreed risk profile
b) Ensure the availability of flexible competitively priced financing at all times
c) Identify and manage the Trust's financial risks arising from operational activities
d) Ensure compliance with all banking covenants.
Attitude to investment risk
The principal purpose of the treasury function within the Trust is to;
a) Maintain liquidity
b) Mitigate and manage risk
c) Ensure a competitive return within an acceptable risk profile.

The Trust is restricted in relation to the sum of money it can keep in commercial bank accounts, the majority required to be retained in Government Banking Services (GBS). Where this is the case these rules override the competitive return achievable (see paragraph 5.4 below).

As well as generating income in the form of credit interest, funds held in the GBS account also reduce the amount of Public Dividend Capital (PDC) payable by the Trust at a rate of 3.5% per annum. Therefore both the income and reduced expenditure elements need to be considered in relation to GBS balances.
Investment of Surplus Cash - The Trust has limited options for investing its surplus cash and investment with individual institutions should not exceed the following limits at any time:
RBS (on behalf of Government Banking Services) - Unlimited
National Loans Fund (minimum investment £1m) – Unlimited

The Trust has considered the likelihood of surplus funds for investment and considers that the PDC reduction as a result of retaining balances with GBs is likely to outweigh any return that could be secured through institutions with sufficient rating with the ratings agencies for the medium term.
Borrowing - All investment in Trust operations will be reviewed by the Finance and Performance Committee and subject to decision by the Trust Board.

The criteria for the borrowing and the rationale for the proposed lender and type of loan will be formally set out to the Trust Board to ensure the transaction meets any perceived risk at the time of the proposed loan.
Organisation and responsibilities
Responsibilities under the Treasury Management Policy are:
6.1.1 Board
a) Approve all external funding arrangements including the Trust's Committed Working Capital Facility and any longer term loans for investment in Trust operational services.
b) Delegate responsibility for approval of treasury procedures, controls and detailed policies to the Finance and Performance Committee.
6.1.2 Finance and Performance Committee
c) Approve the Trust's investment and borrowing policy (where applicable)
d) Approve the relevant benchmarks for measuring performance
e) Review and monitor investment and borrowing policy and performance against agreed benchmarks
f) Ensure there are proper and robust safeguards in place for security of the Trust's monies by:
i)  Agreeing the list of permitted institutions, investment limits and permitted investment types for investment of cash surpluses
ii) Ensuring approved bank mandates are in place for all Trust accounts and that these are updated regularly for any changes in signatories and authority levels
g) Monitor compliance with treasury policy and procedures
h) Delegate responsibility for day to day treasury operations to the Trust's Chief Finance Officer.
6.1.3 Chief Finance Officer
a) Approve cash budgets and forecasts
b) Approve cash management systems
c) Ensure treasury activities are reported appropriately to the Finance and Investment Committee and the Trust Board
d) Manage key banking relationships
e) Report on a regular basis on the appropriateness of the Treasury Management Policy to the Finance and Performance Committee
f) Approve Trust purchase cards and temporary changes to credit limits, allowable areas of expenditure, individual limits, and barring of services.
g) Delegate day to day responsibility for treasury management to the Finance Director.
6.1.4 Finance Director
a) Ensure treasury activities are managed according to the Treasury Management Policy
b) Manage day to day banking relationships
c) Ensure timely and accurate information is available to support the management of the treasury function
d) Ensure:
i)  Accurate and timely recording in the Trust's accounting records of all treasury transactions

ii)  Bank reconciliations are carried out weekly by the Financial Accounting team and reviewed by the Financial Accounting Manager monthly with exceptional items being reported to the Director of Finance.
e) Regular review of the Treasury Management Policy and recommending changes in the policy to the Chief Finance Officer.
f) Approve Trust purchase cards and temporary changes to credit limits, allowable areas of expenditure, individual limits, and barring of services.
6.1.5 Head of Financial Accounting
a)  Approve Trust purchase cards and temporary changes to credit limits, allowable areas of expenditure, individual limits, and barring of services.
Bank relationships and cash management
The development and maintenance of strong banking relationships is an important and key factor in enabling the Trust to manage its cash and to enable access to funds for future service expansion.
Key objectives in this area are to:
a) Ensure the cost paid for banking services is competitive
b) Minimise the cost of borrowing and maximise the return on cash surpluses within acceptable risk parameters
c) To develop and maintain a strong relationship with a bank (or a number of banks)
d) Monitor and ensure compliance with banking covenants.
The Chief Finance Officer is responsible for managing all banking relationships and ensuring a consistency of approach across all banking services to achieve the optimum benefits for the Trust.
The Trust currently has key relationships with two banking institutions.
a) RBS (NatWest) – provider of the GBS
b) Barclays Bank PLC (Charity Account only)
These banks provide the following facilities to the Trust:
7.5.1 RBS (NatWest):
Chaps Receipts and Chaps Payments
Bacs Receipts
Payable Orders
Bacs Payments
A range of faster payment and international payment options
Local Banking
7.5.2 Barclays:
Income Collection Account
Local Banking
Reporting
The regular reporting of treasury management is crucial in ensuring all relevant parties:
a) Are aware of transactions undertaken
b) Can understand the Trust's cash position
c) Can assess the on-going appropriateness of the treasury objective.
To facilitate the requirements set out above the Trust will produce the following reports:
Daily Movement Report - This will include the opening and closing net cash
position, the facility available and any amount drawn down, a summary of all borrowings and lending, a review of any banking covenant position.
- Produced by Deputy Finance Manager
- Circulated to the Finance Director and Head of Financial Accounting for their review
Monthly Treasury Report - An analysis of cash/borrowing/lendings
- Covenant compliance (as applicable)
- Liquidity and security of any funding (as applicable)
- Debtor days
- Creditor days
- Gearing and interest rate cover (and exposure)
- A review of cash and working capital movements
- A monthly cash forecast for the next year
- Performance monitoring criteria reported on by exception
- Reviewed by Finance Director
- Circulated to Trust Executive Committee and Finance and Performance Committee through the integrated performance report.
Treasury Controls

The overall objective of the procedures set out below is to ensure treasury activities are undertaken in a controlled manner to ensure the Trust is not exposed to undue operational risk. In particular:
a) There is a segregation of duties between staff who initiate payments and account for transactions
b) All confirmation of transactions from counterparties are checked and recorded in the Trust's financial ledger by Cash Management
c) All transactions are recorded in the Trust's cash management system
d) all payment instructions/confirmations require authorised signatories in accordance with the Trust's internal policies
e) Mandates are regularly reviewed and sent to all counterparties.
Authorisation Procedure – Creditors: Payment of Creditors
9.2.1 The Financial Services team enter creditor invoices onto the workflow system for appropriate authorisation by budget holders or their delegates.
9.2.2 The Financial Services team prepares and checks a list of outstanding creditors to be paid.
9.2.3 The Financial Services Manager checks the payments list for errors.
9.2.4 The BACS Schedules are then checked and authorised by the Financial Accounting Manager or an appropriate equivalent who also checks there are sufficient funds available to make the payment
9.2.5 Schedules for payment to third parties from the Trust bank accounts are then authorised in accordance with this Policy.
9.2.6 Authorised BACS schedules are communicated to the BACS provider electronically, Deputy Financial Accountants, to ensure segregation of duties.
9.2.7 Automated electronic remittance advice sent to suppliers via email relating to BACS transactions.
9.2.8 If an email is not available for a supplier then a hard copy remittance advice is posted.

9.2.9 Cheques are produced in only exceptional ad hoc circumstances, these are confirmed to be paid by the Financial Accounting Manager or a deemed equivalent and the appropriate authorised signatories are obtained in accordance with relevant mandate.
Trust Purchase Cards
9.3.1 Trust purchase cards will only be issued to staff authorised by the Chief Finance Officer or Finance Director.

9.3.2 All cardholders are required to authorise and return their card statements to the Financial Accounting team on a monthly basis. Failure to return a statement or a reconciliation will result in the card being suspended.

9.3.3 Any temporary changes to credit limits, individual limits and barring of services will be administered by the Financial Accounting Team and individually authorised by the Chief Finance officer or Finance Director. The limit and categories available on individual cards are tailored to the needs of the service area to which it relates.
9.3.4 A  master list of issued cards, authorisation and credit limits is maintained and managed by the Financial Accounting Team.
9.3.5 All  transactions  relating  to  Trust  purchase  cards  are  recorded  on  the  Trust's Finance System by the Financial Accounting Team.
Imprest Accounts

9.4.1 The Trust has imprest accounts on each hospital site. If it is determined that a further imprest account is necessary, then authorisation for the account will be subject to approval by the Chief Finance Officer or Finance Director.
9.4.2 Imprest account holders are also required to submit a monthly reconciliation of cash drawn and expenditure made to the Treasury Management Team.
Training requirements
No specific training requirements.

data.text: Approval and implementation

All policies, procedures and guidelines will be approved by the Finance and Performance Committee which is the specialist group with the authority to approve local finance policies and documents. These will then be forwarded to the Document control team for submission and ratification by the Joint Document Management Group.
It is the author's responsibility to inform the Finance and Performance Committee of the approved policy documents when they are uploaded to the Trust's Intranets.
Equality impact assessment
The Trust is committed to the provision of a service that is fair, accessible and meets the needs of all individuals.
